s.text: Since all genetic studies have recognized that a large number of genes are involved in autoimmune disease susceptibility, the potential for a transgene to hit one of those susceptibility genes is not negligible.
In spite of this great complexity, advances have been made, and a small but growing number of susceptibility genes have been identified (Morahan and Morel 2002).
In spite of this great complexity, advances have been made, and a small but growing number of susceptibility genes have been identified (Morahan and Morel 2002).
In spite of this great complexity, advances have been made, and a small but growing number of susceptibility genes have been identified (Morahan and Morel 2002).
What the new study of Botto and colleagues reminds us is that the appropriate control is still crucial to meaningful data interpretation.
A common trait shared by successful studies has been the use of mouse models, either directly or indirectly.

The identification of the most common genetic and environmental factors that set off autoimmunity may lead to a better understanding of the ensuing pathogenesis, and offers the best hope for improved therapies, and ultimately, cures.

In this context, the autoimmune phenotypes resulting from the combination of the 129 and B6 genomes may might therefore provide a primed background upon which the effects of deficiency in the target gene can be amplified.
On the other hand, the autoimmune phenotype may be overwhelmingly contributed by the (129 ? B6) genomic combination, with little if any effect of the deficiency of the KO gene.
Consequently, this strain combination is at the origin of the overwhelming majority of knockout strains.
Consequently, this strain combination is at the origin of the overwhelming majority of knockout strains.
